item.title: Covid: Moderna vaccine UK rollout begins in Wales
item.description: The vaccine is the third to be used in the UK, with England's rollout due "in the next few days".

item.title: Andy Marsh: Avon and Somerset Police chief to leave role
item.description: Avon and Somerset Police has faced criticism of its handling of Black Lives Matter and Kill the Bill protests.

item.title: Newcastle driver left student to die in road after crash
item.description: Emma Guilbert was on a crossing when Mohammed Youssaf crashed into her and drove off.

item.title: Susan Waring: Family plead with murderer to say where 'beloved' is
item.description: Alan Edwards will serve 27 years for the murder of Susan Waring, whose body has never been found.

item.title: Buddhist monk freed from flooded cave in Thailand after four days
item.description: Monk who entered cave "to sit in contemplation" is rescued by divers after four days trapped inside.

item.title: Pharrell Williams calls for investigation after cousin shot dead by police
item.description: The Grammy-winning artist's cousin, Donovon Lynch, was shot and killed in Virginia by police.

item.title: Driving lessons to resume in England and Wales on 12 April
item.description: Lessons can start on 12 April and tests will return 10 days later, the transport secretary says.

item.title: Covid: Young and poor more likely to be lonely in lockdown
item.description: Loneliness in the pandemic has been more intense for young people in poor, urban areas.

item.title: TikTok: Teen saves boy after seeing crash on livestream
item.description: The 13-year-old raised the alarm after the boy crashed his quad bike during a live feed.

item.title: Mobile phones should be banned in schools - Gavin Williamson
item.description: Phones should not be used or seen during the school day, the education secretary says.

item.title: Carlisle ex-police officer 'devastated' by Â£3k Royal Mail scam
item.description: The officer of 25 years felt "helpless and angry" after falling victim to a Royal Mail parcel scam.

item.title: 'Covid-breach' kayaker stuck on Loch Lomond island without paddle
item.description: The man, believed to be from England, was rescued after getting trapped while camping on Inchtavannach in Loch Lomond.

item.title: Road sign blunders see Saxilby and Thorpe on the Hill renamed
item.description: The misspelt signs on Lincoln's bypass prompted much mirth among local residents.

item.title: Four quizzed over 8,000 bluebells dug up in wood
item.description: Four people are questioned by police after 8,000 bulbs are found in bags in a wood.

item.title: 'I could photograph space my entire life'
item.description: A paediatrician describes how his love of space observation has grown during the lockdown.

item.title: Inner Light: The children surviving conflict in DR Congo
item.description: Hugh Kinsella Cunningham documents the lives of children caught up in conflict in DR Congo.

item.title: How one woman discovered her true cultural heritage
item.description: Gail Lukasik's life was turned upside down when she discovered her mother was mixed race but had 'passed' as white to escape racial segregation in the US.

item.title: Hazmat crew called in to clean US house
item.description: The resident has been dealing with depression and fatigue following a stroke over 20 years ago.

item.title: The Papers: 'Pause jabs for young people', and holidays latest
item.description: Wednesday's newspaper front pages carry a mix of stories although coronavirus continues to dominate.

item.title: US restaurants face ketchup packet shortage amid Covid pandemic
item.description: The coronavirus pandemic leads to a surge in demand for single-use packs of the popular condiment.

item.title: Dutch crew rescued from 'near-capsize'
item.description: The crew were forced to abandon ship when the sea got really rough.

item.title: Mother-daughter relationship turned upside down by Covid
item.description: Margaret and Cordelia have seen a reversal in their financial relationship due to the pandemic.

item.title: Snow in Wales: Sunny Easter weather a distant memory
item.description: From Llanbrynmair to Llandovery, the white stuff made an unseasonable return as spring got under way.

item.title: Chris Sutton: 'I believe heading a football killed my dad'
item.description: Chris Sutton has opened up about the struggle of watching his dad, footballer Mike Sutton, suffer with dementia.

item.title: Bronze Age slab found in France is oldest 3D map in Europe
item.description: The Bronze Age engravings are a map of part of Brittany, north-west France, researchers believe.

item.title: China one-child policy: can dropping limits increase birth rates?
item.description: The government is considering dropping birth limits in some parts to offset an ageing population.

item.title: 'Long Covid has destroyed me but I am fighting back'
item.description: A former health coach is blogging about her experience with the condition to help others get diagnosed.

item.title: Another Round: How a film about a drinking experiment became a celebration of life
item.description: Another Round sees four men on an alcohol experiment and has become an Oscar-nominated success.

item.title: Why Utah is making men pay women's pregnancy costs
item.description: Fathers in Utah will soon be legally obligated to foot half the bill of a mother's pregnancy.

item.title: India Covid-19: 'No end in sight' as doctors battle second wave
item.description: Indian doctors say they are already feeling overwhelmed as Covid cases rise sharply in the country.

item.title: Huber case: Nazi police chief in Vienna spied for West Germany
item.description: German spy agency reveals that a top Nazi who sent Jews to their deaths helped it after the war.

item.title: Jordan crisis: How Prince Hamzah and Saudi Arabia fit in
item.description: Saudi officials categorically deny suggestions their country had any role in an alleged coup attempt.

item.title: Greenland election: Opposition win casts doubt on mine
item.description: The victorious left-wing party opposes a planned mine which has powerful international backers.

item.title: Tool checks phone numbers from Facebook data breach
item.description: A new online tool lets users check their phone numbers against the leaked database.

item.title: 'Utterly unacceptable' - Liverpool condemn online racist abuse sent to Alexander-Arnold and Keita
item.description: Liverpool say racist abuse on social media "cannot be allowed to continue" after Trent Alexander-Arnold and Naby Keita are both targeted.

item.title: Capacity crowd to watch World Championship final at Crucible
item.description: The final of the World Championship is set to be played in front of a capacity crowd at the Crucible Theatre in May.

item.title: 'Brilliant Foden has final word over fellow emerging superstar Haaland - for now'
item.description: On a night when headlines were focused on Borussia Dortmund superstar Erling Braut Haaland, it was Manchester City's Phil Foden who had the final word.

item.title: Middlesbrough's Riverside Stadium to host England friendlies
item.description: Middlesbrough's Riverside Stadium will host two England friendlies in preparation for this summer's European Championship.

item.title: Kevin de Bruyne: Man City midfielder signs new deal that runs until 2025
item.description: Manchester City midfielder Kevin de Bruyne signs a new deal running until 2025 with the Premier League leaders.

item.title: Office workers as team-mates and less 'kick tennis' - England lock Kruis on life in Japan
item.description: How a conversation with England coach Eddie Jones set Lions forward George Kruis on his way to Panasonic Wild Knights.

item.title: Real Madrid 3-1 Liverpool: 'Another Anfield rescue act looks beyond Liverpool now' - Mark Lawrenson
item.description: Liverpool have a rich history of turning around Champions League ties at Anfield, says ex-Reds defender Mark Lawrenson, but it is hard to see a revival against Real Madrid next week.

item.title: Covid: How does the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine work?
item.description: The prime minister has urged people to trust medical regulators about the safety of the vaccine.

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: The Moderna vaccine has become the third vaccine to be used in the UK, joining Oxford-Astra Zeneca and Pfizer.

item.title: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: The rules on how many people can meet outdoors are changing, as lockdown is eased.

item.title: Can Covid be spread by vaping? And other questions
item.description: We answer some of your questions about England's roadmap out of lockdown, and other Covid-related issues.

item.title: Covid vaccine update: Those that work - and the others on the way
item.description: Covid vaccination campaigns are under way in the UK and across the world.

item.title: Covid: How to get a test for coronavirus
item.description: What are the tests for coronavirus, who are they for, and how do they work?

item.title: Covid: When can I go on holiday abroad or in the UK?
item.description: Anyone in England who travels abroad without good reason will soon face a Â£5000 fine.

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The logistics of vaccinating millions of people across the country, as more than 31 million people receive at least one dose.

item.title: What are the UK plans for Covid passports?
item.description: The government is considering how people could prove they are unlikely to transmit Covid.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in your area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Covid: What is the rule of six and what are the social distancing rules?
item.description: Lockdown rules are being eased further in England and Wales so more people can meet up outside.

item.title: Covid: Can my boss force me to go to work?
item.description: As lockdown restrictions ease ease gradually across the UK, what are the rules about going to work?

item.title: Covid vaccines: How fast is progress around the world?
item.description: Charts and maps tracking the progress of Covid vaccination programmes.

item.title: Coronavirus: When will pools, gyms and hairdressers open?
item.description: Lockdown has been eased further - but what does it mean for hairdressers, pubs and gyms?

item.title: Covid: When can pubs and restaurants reopen?
item.description: Hospitality venues are set to gradually open up in the spring as lockdown eases across the UK.

item.title: Lockdown rules: What are the restrictions in your area?
item.description: Use our search tool to find out about coronavirus rules and restrictions where you live.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the rules for places of worship?
item.description: Places of worship are open across much of the UK, despite lockdown.

item.title: Coronavirus: Your tributes to those who have died
item.description: A collection of your tributes to some of the thousands of people in the UK who have died with coronavirus.

item.title: Why is the EU unhappy with AstraZeneca?
item.description: The EU has called on AstraZeneca to "catch up" on its deliveries to the EU.

item.title: What are the rules for weddings and when can I hold a reception?
item.description: Wedding ceremonies are still restricted across the UK, but the rules are easing.

item.title: Covid: Whatâs the problem with the EU vaccine rollout?
item.description: The coronavirus vaccine is being rolled out across the EU but there have been delays.

item.title: Covid: How are European countries tackling the pandemic?
item.description: Are European countries relaxing restrictions put in place to control a new wave of infections?

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the rules for face masks or face coverings?
item.description: As the UK cautiously unlocks, experts will review the evidence on when and where masks are needed.

item.title: Covid: What's happened to crime during the pandemic?
item.description: From dog theft to drug crime, lockdown has led to some big changes in policing.

item.title: Unemployment rate: How many people are out of work?
item.description: The unemployment rate is rising as Covid hits different parts of the economy.

item.title: Covid: The inside story of the government's battle against the virus
item.description: Twenty of Downing Street's most senior politicians, officials and former officials take you "into the room" where essential Covid decisions were being made.

item.title: Covid: The countries that nailed it, and what we can learn from them
item.description: A year into the pandemic, we look at countries that have had some success in tackling the virus.

item.title: Race report: Was controversy part of the plan?
item.description: How the government handled the release of a contentious report on racial disparity in the UK.

item.title: 'We found a baby on the subway - now he's our son'
item.description: Danny Stewart saw something on the floor of an NY subway station - soon he would treasure it more than anything.

item.title: Letterbox contact: âDonât my birth children have a right to know Iâm dying?'
item.description: Diagnosed with a terminal illness, Hanna wanted to tell the twins taken from her at 16 - but had no way of reaching them.

item.title: The cost of speaking up against China
item.description: Uyghurs abroad describe a pattern of harassment and intimidation they say is designed to silence them.

item.title: The vaccine misinformation battle raging in France
item.description: Online conspiracy theories are exacerbating existing vaccine scepticism.
